ContentClassification.TableReference: The Executive Committee of the Continuous Mortality Improvement Bureau, “Standard Tables of Mortality Based on the 1991-94 Experiences”, Continuous Mortality Improvement Reports Number 17, Institute of Actuaries and Faculty of Actuaries (1999). Accessed: November, 2013 from http://www.actuaries.org.uk/research-and-resources/pages/92-series-mortality-tables-assured-lives-annuitants-and-pensioners AND http://www.actuaries.org.uk/research-and-resources/documents/cmi-report-17-whole-volume
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Pensioners with Normal Retirement and Mortality Improvement Projection - Female. Basis: Amounts (PFA92C10). Minimum Issue Age: 20. Maximum Issue Age: 120.
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: Table is part of the "92" series of mortality tables for assured lives, annuitants and pensioners. The Continuous Mortality Improvement Bureau carries out investigations for both sexes, on the basis both of Lives and of Amounts, and the experience is divided into those who retired at or after their normal pension age (referred to as 'normal') and those who retired before their normal age (referred to as 'early'). Methodology: Experiences graduated by fitting µx to a Gompertz-Makeham formula. Age ranges were fitted independently to a series of formulae which are extensions of the Gompertz-Makeham (GM), using Chebysheff polynomials. Five different formulae were used for different age ranges. The Committee was of the view that it would be imprudent not to incorporate into the new tables (See SOA Table Identities 2365 and 2368) an allowance for projected improvements in mortality. This table represents a projection through 2010. Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 11/2013.

MetaData.TableDescription: Pensioners with Normal Retirement and Mortality Improvement Projection - Female. Basis: Amounts (PFA92C10). Minimum Issue Age: 20. Maximum Issue Age: 120.
